headline: Holiday E-Commerce Sales Hit Record, Adobe Says. AI Chatbots Are Taking Off.
summary: U.S. consumers didn’t let inflation or rising interest rates slow down their online shopping this past holiday season.  People spent $241.4 billion online from Nov. 1 to Dec. 31, 8.7% more than last year,  Adobe  said, far outstripping the gain in purchases at stores reported elsewhere.  Markdowns for electronics peaked at 30.1% off listed prices, while apparel discounts peaked at 23.2%, Adobe said.

headline: Price-Sensitive Shoppers Drove Online Sales Growth This Holiday Season
summary: Online shoppers were set on saving money this holiday season, according to new data, but that didn't stop them from spending.

raw.headline: Price-Sensitive Shoppers Drove Online Sales Growth This Holiday Season
raw.summary: Online shoppers were set on saving money this holiday season, according to new data, but that didn't stop them from spending.

headline: US online holiday sales rise nearly 9% on mobile shopping boom, report shows
summary: Holiday spending from Nov. 1 through Dec. 31 rose 8.7% to about $241.4 billion online, higher than Adobe's initial forecast of $240.8 billion made in September.  Retailers, including Walmart and Target, spent more on ads, offered early discounts and targeted promotions, and used artificial intelligence to drive sales during a shorter holiday season and draw in bargain-hungry customers.  But, the higher-than-forecast jump in online spending may not translate into profits for retailers, said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management in Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin.

raw.headline: US online holiday sales rise nearly 9% on mobile shopping boom, report shows

Retailers, including Walmart and Target, spent more on ads, offered early discounts and targeted promotions, and used artificial intelligence to drive sales during a shorter holiday season and draw in bargain-hungry customers.  But, the higher-than-forecast jump in online spending may not translate into profits for retailers, said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management in Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin.

headline: 2024 holiday shopping was the 'most mobile of all time'
summary: The 2024 holiday shopping season saw a record $241.4 billion in online spending, an 8.7% increase from the previous year. As inflation continued to press on consumers, a combination of competitive discounts, convenience, and a shift to mobile shopping drove growth.

headline: Adobe: Holiday Shopping Season Drove a Record $241.4 Billion Online and Rising 8.7% YoY
summary: SAN JOSE, Calif., January 07, 2025--Today, Adobe (Nasdaq:ADBE) released online shopping data for the 2024 holiday season, covering the period from Nov. 1 through Dec. 31, 2024. Based on Adobe Analytics data, the analysis provides the most comprehensive view into U.S. e-commerce by analyzing commerce transactions online, covering over 1 trillion visits to U.S. retail sites, 100 million SKUs and 18 product categories.
